headline.main: Dedication of a New Cemetery at Flushing

docs.lead_paragraph: The dedication of a new Cemetery, for the use of all denominations, took place yesterday, near Flushing. It is located about two miles outside the town, and is pleasantly situated But little or no ornamental work has been done in the ground, although one tenant of the tomb even already rests there--a chill having been recently interred within its borders.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New- York Daily Times : Having learned that an unfavorable impression was obtained by some people, from my article about the water-spirits in Dr. BEDERTHA'S establishment, I am inclined, in a more presy way, which will perhaps be more easily understood, to correct it. I certainly meant to do good rather than evil;

docs.lead_paragraph: Galveston papers of the 19th, and Indianola papers of the 16th inst. have been received. The Indianola Bulletin says: Since our last we have had excessive rains and cold weather. We fear this may exert an unfavorable influence on cotton in its present state. By a gentleman who has just traveled through Wharton and Matagorda counties, we learn that the crops of sugar and cotton over there are remarkably fine.

headline.main: THE TRADES IN NEW-YORK.; Great Mass Mee ting at Metropolitan Hall. The Journeymen House-Painters Sustained.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last night, a vast multitude of the different trades of the City assembled at Metropolitan Hall, for the pur pose of expressing their sympathy with, and giving their active support to the House-Painters, with the history of whose strike the public are now pretty familiar. The body of the room, where the Painters, whom the meeting most immediately concerned, were for the most part seated, was as full as the sitting-accommodation could possibly admit of.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is a singular and instructive phenomenon that the current years are summoned to witness. The nations of the Old World are drifting from their moorings, and are once more at the mercy of the waves of time and circumstance. They can no longer find safe anchorage in the ancient roadstead. but labor heavily on the swell of their troubled seas.
